qas.question: What is the purpose of charms?

answers.text: provides access to system and app-related functions, such as search, sharing, device management, settings, and a Start button

qas.question: How is an active list of apps accessed?

answers.text: Pointing the cursor in the top-left corner of the screen and moving down

qas.question: What does swiping from the left edge of the screen do?

answers.text: allows one to switch between apps and Desktop

qas.question: How is the traditional desktop evironment opened?

answers.text: via a tile on the Start screen

plausible_answers.text: provides access to system and app-related functions, such as search, sharing, device management, settings, and a Start button

qas.question: What isn't the purpose of charms?

plausible_answers.text: Pointing the cursor in the top-left corner of the screen and moving down

qas.question: How is an inactive list of apps accessed?

plausible_answers.text: allows one to switch between apps and Desktop

qas.question: What does swiping from the right edge of the screen do?

plausible_answers.text: via a tile on the Start screen

qas.question: How is the traditional desktop evironment closed?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>A vertical toolbar<b5_0/><a0_0/> known as the charms (accessed by swiping from the right edge of a touchscreen, or pointing the cursor at hotspots in the right corners of a screen) <a1_0><b6_0>provides access to system and app-related functions, such as search, sharing, device management, settings, and a Start button<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The traditional desktop environment for running desktop applications is accessed <a4_0><b9_0>via a tile on the Start screen<b9_0/><a4_0/>. The Start button on the taskbar from previous versions of Windows has been converted into a hotspot in the lower-left corner of the screen, which displays a large tooltip displaying a thumbnail of the Start screen. Swiping from the left edge of a touchscreen or clicking in the top-left corner of the screen <a3_0><b8_0>allows one to switch between apps and Desktop<b8_0/><a3_0/>. <a2_0><b7_0>Pointing the cursor in the top-left corner of the screen and moving down<b7_0/><a2_0/> reveals a thumbnail list of active apps. Aside from the removal of the Start button and the replacement of the Aero Glass theme with a flatter and solid-colored design, the desktop interface on Windows 8 is similar to that of Windows 7.
